title: What Does the Number 10 Mean in the Bible?

steps.title: In the Bible, 10 signifies responsibility, power, and divine completion.
steps.content: In the Bible, 10 signifies responsibility, power, and divine completion. Numerically, the number 10 is seen as a complete or perfect number, and its appearance in the Bible is no different. [1] X Research source 10 is the sum of 4 and 6—with 4 representing physical creation and 6 indicating man. Together, these numbers create 10, embodying the Lord’s almighty power and grace. God has a big responsibility to watch over humankind, and 10 is a reflection of that. When the number 10 appears in the Bible, it’s typically in relation to something being completed because of God’s power. [2] X Research source In Judaism, 10 is sometimes believed to mean “union” or “collection,” as rabbis deemed it a holy number. The tenth number of the Hebrew alphabet is yod, which means “hand of God” and “continuity.” [3] X Trustworthy Source Chabad.org Online resource for information related to Chabad-Lubavitch and Jewish culture Go to source It’s believed that the number 10 is in the Bible over 240 times.

steps.title: “God said” is used 10 times to describe the creation of the world.
steps.content: “God said” is used 10 times to describe the creation of the world. The number 10 signifies divine completion in Genesis 1 as the powerful phrase “God said” is used 10 times to describe how God created the world. For example, “Then God said, ‘Let us make mankind in our image, in our likeness, so that they may rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky, over the livestock and all the wild animals, and over all the creatures that move along the ground” (Genesis 1:26). [4] X Research source Similarly, in Genesis 1, the Lord creates 10 things on the first day of creation, 10 on the sixth day, and 10 on the final day. [5] X Research source

steps.title: God gave His followers 10 Commandments to live by.
steps.content: God gave His followers 10 Commandments to live by. One of the most well-known depictions of 10 in the Bible is the appearance of the Commandments in Exodus. On Mount Sinai, Moses receives 10 Commandments or golden rules from the Lord. It is these rules Christians must live by in the name of God. [6] X Research source Some theorize that the order of the 10 Commandments holds a more significant meaning. The first 4 are directed toward God (e.g., “You shall have no other gods before Me”), while the other six regard human relationships (e.g., “You shall not murder”). This distinction may represent God’s power and divine completion.

steps.title: 10 Plagues wash over the Egyptians in Exodus.
steps.content: 10 Plagues wash over the Egyptians in Exodus. When the Pharaoh refused to let the Hebrews go and kept them enslaved, God unleashed His power with 10 plagues. The most notable plague was the tenth, which killed every firstborn son in Egypt, including the Pharaoh’s. [7] X Research source These 10 Plagues represent God’s judgment and authority over man.

steps.title: The number 10 signifies sacrifice and repentance on the Jewish calendar.
steps.content: The number 10 signifies sacrifice and repentance on the Jewish calendar. The number 10 makes many appearances throughout the Jewish calendar, with the most notable occurrences being: A Passover lamb is chosen on the 10th day of the first month. [8] X Research source One must repent for 10 days between Rosh Hashanah or Feast of Trumpets. [9] X Research source

steps.title: There are 10 generations between Adam and Noah.
steps.content: There are 10 generations between Adam and Noah. Adam was the first son of God in the Garden of Eve, and Noah was a faithful servant to God who built an ark. Ten generations passed between Adam and Noah’s stories when God claimed man was corrupt and decided to destroy all humankind (outside of Noah and his family on the ark). [10] X Research source In other words, 10 generations of man lived before The Flood. Similarly, 10 generations passed between Noah and Abraham, a friend and servant of God who was incredibly faithful and loyal. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Jesus speaks of 10 virgins in Matthew.
steps.content: Jesus speaks of 10 virgins in Matthew. In Matthew 25:1-13, Jesus talks to a parable about 10 virgins who symbolize faith and unfaithfulness. Here, the number 10 represents the completeness of God’s judgment. [12] X Research source “At that time, the kingdom of heaven will be like ten virgins who took their lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom. Five of them were foolish, and five were wise” (Matthew 25:1-2). [13] X Research source

steps.title: There are 10 tribes of Israel.
steps.content: There are 10 tribes of Israel. As shown in 1 Kings 12:19-20 and 2 Chronicles 11:1-4, 10 tribes separated from the kingdom of Judah. [14] X Research source This signifies the completeness of the Christian faith and God’s desire for unity. “So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day. When all the Israelites heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent and called him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to the house of David” (1 Kings 12:19-20). [15] X Research source “‘This is what the Lord says: Do not go up to fight against your fellow Israelites. Go home, every one of you, for this is my doing’” (2 Chronicles 11:4). [16] X Research source

steps.title: There are 10 lost books mentioned in the Old Testament.
steps.content: There are 10 lost books mentioned in the Old Testament. Many theorize that the Bible we read today wasn’t meant to be the final version. The Old Testament refers to books not in the Bible, and scholars refer to these as the “lost books.” These books aren’t necessarily lost but missing or taken out of the Bible’s final publication. [17] X Research source These include: The Book of the Wars of the Lord The Book of Jasher The Book of the Acts of Solomon The Book of Nathan the Prophet The Book of Gad the Seer The Prophecy of Ahijah the Shiloite The Visions of Iddo the Seer The Book of Shemaiah the Prophet The Book of Jehu the Son of Hanani The Sayings of Hosai

steps.title: In the Bible, John 10:10 is Jesus’s mission statement to give Christians eternal life.
steps.content: In the Bible, John 10:10 is Jesus’s mission statement to give Christians eternal life. John 10:10 is as follows: “The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy; I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full.” [18] X Research source This is a powerful verse that embodies Jesus’s mission to help Christians live an abundant life. In the Bible, God’s people are sheep and Jesus is the shepherd. In this allegory, the thieves Jesus refers to in John 10:10 are those who try to steer God’s people wrong. It is God’s word and Jesus’s mission to forgive the thieves and lead them on a path of Christianity to an abundant life. [19] X Research source Jesus explains that an abundant life is an eternal life: “My sheep listen to my voice; I know them, and they follow me. I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish; no one will snatch them out of my hand” (John 10:27-28). [20] X Research source

steps.title: In Hebrew, the word for the number 10 means “wealth,” which relates to tithing.
steps.content: In Hebrew, the word for the number 10 means “wealth,” which relates to tithing. The Hebrew word for the number 10 is eser , which sounds very similar to the Hebrew word for “wealth,” osher . [21] X Research source Because of this connection, many Christians believe the number 10 is associated with tithing, which is the practice of giving one-tenth of one’s earnings to the church. In Biblical times, the law required Israelites to give 10% of their goods. [22] X Research source As the scripture says: “Every tithe of the herd and flock—every tenth animal that passes under the shepherd’s rod—will be holy to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). [23] X Research source “Be sure to set aside a tenth of all that your fields produce each year” (Deuteronomy 14:22). [24] X Research source “Honor the Lord with your wealth, with the first fruits of all your crops” (Proverbs 3:9). [25] X Research source

steps.title: The number 10 is important because it signifies God’s almighty power.
steps.content: The number 10 is important because it signifies God’s almighty power. There’s no denying that the number 10 is powerful, and how it’s used in the Bible and what it represents is extremely significant. The number 10 primarily comes with catastrophic and life-altering events. For instance, the 10 Plagues of Egypt and the 10 Commandments. These events altered Christians' lives and showcased the Lord's almighty power. Because of this, the number 10 represents God’s strength and effort to execute divine completion.
